Sociology is in no way a science. The fact is, if any field/discipline/school of thought etc is going to make a claim about something in the way a "science" would, they must Provide, observable, reproducible, quantifiable evidence to support their claim, while clearly and descriptively outlining their materials, methods, timeline, and prior research supporting the plausibility of their hypothesis. This is the BARE MINIMUM just to consider a claim as tenable (and thus be a scientific claim). This isnt even mentioning other constraints, such as false positives/negatives,  Fundamental Attribution Error, and false dichotomies.  The reality is that  sociology, and many of which include (but are not limited to) gender theory, cultural theory, women studies, religious studies etc, fail to meet these minimal expectations in substantiating their claims (as their methods are limited to anectodotal observation,  surveys and selection batteries, all of which have a low amount of reliability and validity agaisnt something like say a double blind placebo study)  This limits these fields almost exclusively to the realm of conjecture and disqualifies them from being considered anything that can be even mistaken as a science.

For my sociology A-level coursework I decided to look at the problem of low breastfeeding rates in the UK. My hypothesis was that social class would be the main predictor of whether a mother will initiate breastfeeding. I worked out my methodology -collecting primary raw objective facts by interviewing a random sample of new mothers, and I found that class was not the primary predictor for initiating breastfeeding, and that it was actually whether the mother grew up with their biological father in the home or not. I applied a statistical model to my result and found it was statistically significant. My research could be repeated by others to see whether they could replicate my findings.

After 6 months, in the UK, there is another huge drop of mothers breastfeeding. This is more of a macro effect than the micro effect of the initiation of breastfeeding. To find out why, a sociologist could use comparative research trying to find what the difference is between the countries with high breastfeeding rates and those with low rates. This is like a scientist changing variables in an experiment.
Now with the internet, simulations technology and processing power, sociologists are going to have access to a wealth of objective data which will allow them to discover facts about society which will allow them to make predictions.

Bear in mind here that the word critical doesn't mean 'expressing or involving an analysis of the merits and faults of an idea/set of ideas'. Here it means 'targetting structures of power and oppression' because that's basically how they think change is brought.

So why are there people at all saying that sociology isn't a science? I think sociology ís a science. I think it has problems that don't occur with STEM fields like physics or chemistry.

In physics, if your statistics are off or your formulas don't work, your rocket isn't going to fly.
In sociology, you measure people. The closer you get to social interactions, the more difficult it gets to measure people. E.g. you don't know whether or not what you are measuring is the thing you want to measure (the validity of a test). This is a big problem in social psychology, but I digress.

Even with big data sets, on population for example, you can interpret a set of data however you like. Justify your perspective by calling it value-driven sociology, and you basically have a free ticket to do what you want with it. Because, hey, you want to change the world.

Neither sociology nor psychology are hard sciences. They may use the scientific method, but they are not scientists. If we have free-will, or even if compatibilism is true, then predictability and repeatable research is hard to come by. Although if compatibilism is true then we can at least get a general idea about human behavior the same was we can get general information about the way dogs behave-- specifics vary from dog to dog.  However, if hard determinism is true, then both sociology and psychology can make it as a science because causes can be replicated to produce a predicted effect (see: Neuroscience). Some branches of behavioral science is completely useless like evolutionary psychology,  which seems to be based on observations and conjecture. If you've ever read "Why do Beautiful People Have More Daughters" you'll know what I mean. Then there's the problem with researchers being subjective and bias when analyzing data, like Freud, Watson, Skinner, Zimbardo, and to a lesser extent Milgram. This isn't to say psychology or sociology is useless, just that their usefulness is limited.
Let's just say that social sciences are not exact sciences...

I'm trying to be as fair minded as I can here. I want to give sociology a fair crack of the whip because societies are obviously super interesting. Positivist sociology seems fine but the interpretative and especially the critical approaches seem to rest on dubious foundations to me.

Doesn't interpretive sociology presuppose that people understand their own behaviour and motiviations? A zoologist would never imagine that an animal understands itself meaningfully so why make that assumption for humans?

As for critical sociology, isn't that just a well-thought, evidence based, opinion?

I'm not saying that there's no value in these methods of inquiry, but the point of science (as far as I understand it) is to use methods that strip away subjective values and biases to understand the world more clearly. Considering this, I can understand why people would think ill of sociology as a science.

PS: I'm gonna watch all these videos and am open to changing my mind, it's not like I have a PhD in epistemology or anything.

I think the topic of sociology is generating a bad name because as a science it is incapable of producing perfect or repeatable results when humans and society are far too complex to understand enough to properly model. I don't think this is a failing that disqualifies it as a science though, just look at another science with the same problem, meteorology. Meteorologists could not hope to model every atom in the atmosphere, ocean, and land to create a perfect forecast and because they are working with such a complex system that changes constantly they are only capable of a limited understanding and of producing forecasts that must adapt and change as the medium they observe changes due to both predicted and unpredictable inputs. If you don't think sociology is a science then how would you explain the science of marketing and product advertising? They may never claim to know how well a product will sell exactly, but by studying their targeted market and understanding how that market would react to various tactics a good marketing agent will almost always score better sales. I think everyone would agree marketing is a great example of how sociology can be applied to real life and sales figures could even be seen as data to compare methods and refine better sales tactics even if the marketing agents are not 100% sure why these tactics appealed to every individual that actually bought the product. Some sciences need to use forecasts or seek general trends and relationships in the data that help develop an understanding of the system as a whole, this does not make sociology a false science, just a tricky one that even the best will get wrong from time to time.

Now as to why I think there is a mild degree of hatred for sociology out there, I think most of that fits into a dislike for what was labeled "critical sociology". As was mentioned, empirical data must be collected properly and from non-biased methods to have any merit, but when the scientists conducting a study have a pre-determined bias and desire for their results to confirm that bias and spur social change those scientists are far more likely to create a flawed study that is nothing more than propaganda to support that social change. Just look up videos on why most science studies are misleading or false and they can explain dozens or even hundreds of ways bias or flaws can seep into a study by accident or on purpose. Of course you don't need to learn anything to know that devoted activists are unlikely to publish results that actually hurt their positions, so that alone makes having an initial bias unhealthy for actually understanding the truth.

One example that comes to mind of a flaw in these types of studies is one that reports sexual violence incidents with suspiciously high percentages such as the classic "1 in 5 girls" statistic. Did only the girls who were exposed to the violence care enough about it to participate in the voluntary survey, did some girls decide to falsely claim they had been victims hoping that it would increase security and prevent any future dangers that they fear, did some or many falsely report thinking they would make up for girls they thought would be too scared to speak up??? On the other hand, maybe the numbers really are accurate or some might believe them even lower than reality because some might still have been unwilling to report. Perhaps making such a survey anonymous would increase false reports by a large amount since girls had little to loose by reporting they were victims and only stood to benefit from policies enacted because of inflated numbers, or perhaps verifying each incident as much as possible with no anonymity would scare off many actual victims resulting in under reporting. That is just one situation I can think of where gathering empirical data would be just about impossible and the results would vary wildly just depending on the methods used to obtain the data even if it was done by a non-biased sociologist with very well thought out methods. Lots of studies are being pumped out and used to justify laws or social change by critical sociologists and it is hated as a dirty weapon in modern culture wars. Because social change or resisting social change is easier with good evidence and reasons to back your personal positions every person of every viewpoint will collect "evidence" generated by both high quality studies and/or flawed studies to rely on. Since we are all trying to justify our positions we will likely see the errors of our opposition while sharing our own flawed studies among our peers with far less scrutiny. Because of this effect we will get the feeling our social opponents are using sociology wrong and hate on the science itself because we can see it abused so often to our detriment.

Humans are often illogical, complex, and filled with bias, so a study of human interactions by humans sounds inherently messy. For topics such as marketing where all involved share the same goals and produce fairly measurable results sociology really seems to shine as a science that seeks to understand human behavior and creates fairly accurate models and tools, but in many applications of critical sociology I think the initial bias that led to creating a study will very often undermine the study itself. Those are my thoughts on the issue anyway, I look forward to more videos and hope the topic tries to stay fair to all sides involved if it approaches politics, beliefs, social morality, or modern activism. I believe there is merit in social change that seeks to improve life for everyone, but perhaps a rapidly changing society is also inherently unstable, hard to balance, and dangerous in some ways as well, so progressive, regressive, and moderate or change resistant forces in society all play important roles.

The confusion comes when people talk about opinions and facts. Facts are assertions about the world that are true whether you acknowledge the or not. To facts change? Yes, indeed they do. As our understanding of the world improves, so is our knowledge about it.

Opinions are statements based on our personal preference. Say for example: vanilla ice cream is the best ice cream in the world. How can you prove to me that it is not? It is a matter of personal taste.

On the other hand, if I assert that the world is flat, I am making an empirical statement of the world. I can be proven right or wrong regardless of my personal preferences.

Every statement that isn't a opinion of personal taste, an order or a question is an empirical statement of the world. Therefore able to be proven right or wrong. Therefore, there is truth.

Briefly, what is truth? It's the correspondence between what is said about the world and the world itself. Is you say something that doesn't correspond with the world, you are lying.

Logical positivism is pretty dead though. At around 1:00 you say that evidence can be verified. The is false. The process of science is a negative process built upon falsification of bad theories, and continued use of theories which have not been proven false. You can never say that the result matching your hypothesis means your theory is verified because there could be some other reason which is precluded from your theory. Take Newtonian physics. We never verified them, but scientist took them as the closest thing to law we had until Einstein showed the world that Newtonian physics were wrong. A theory cannot even be properly called science if it presents and unfalsifiable hypothesis. Science is a process of elimination and educated guesses.

For those interested in this topic. I recommend looking up more info on the logical positivists and their critics. Especially Karl Popper's arguments about falsification.

Yeah, thats what I don't like about sociology. We start off strong with evidence based research, or "positivism", then realize positivism is hard, and give up on it. Good experiment design is hard, and rigorous statistical analysis is hard, but that does not mean you should give up.

Our knowledge of statistics and how to control for variables has come a long way. Now, peoples own opinions of there environment are important, I get that point. But people are constantly shaped by the studies they see, so using their opinions gives a positive feed back loop.

Why is racism a thing? Do people inherently think that different people are worse? If that is true, then it cannot be fixed, so we should hope its not. No, its a learned behavior. Why do people learn it? Because other people tell them racist things, and the world does not seem to contradict it. Then these racist attitudes reinforce the status quo, and we continue.

The point being, the very concepts we use, our subjectivity as you call it, causes the actual behavior. So incorporating this data into your models, especially if they form the basis of your models, will often make these viscous positive feed back loops.

Also, subjectivity is not a thing. A subjective statement is just not a properly qualified phenomenon. So many statements we make are filled with allot of implicit assumptions. This is largely good, since specifying those assumptions is expensive and most people are people and people are fairly uniform. That said, when an unstated assumption brakes, things can be confusing when you don't realize the assumption.

So while some assumptions are always necessary, the realization that you have to make some does not mean you should give up. It means you should build models and parameterize assumptions that concern you, then run rigorous statistical analysis and look for results.

In closing, sociology is hard, really hard. Luckily people can easily be approximated by simple models, so its still doable, but we are smart enough to "game" any models you through at us, known as the Hawthorne effect. I just don't like that sociologists seem to give up on the hard models instead of being more careful. That is why sociology has to work so hard to be a science, because it often isn't.

Not too impressed with the video. While I don't wish to denigrate the idea of social sciences (I'm an economist myself), it is absurd to think that sociology applies the exact same method as the traditional hard sciences. Multiple ideas of what the scientific method is should be considered and I prefer Karl Popper's idea that scientific theories should be universal and research should be undertaken to actively falsify the theory. Social sciences obviously cannot do this in the way that the hard sciences do because people are so much more complicated and it is much harder to account for confounding variables. I say this not because I want to criticise the subject, but a self-awareness of the subject's limits is required.

BIAS ALERT! "Normative" does not entail "subjective" (nor does "positive" entail "objective"). The value part is right though. Normative theories are about what OUGHT to be -- which may or may not have objective answers according to different people, but you can't just come down conclusively on the "no objective answers" side of things. Positive theories, on the other hand, are about what IS; and such claims CAN be every bit as subjective as normative claims, even if there's general consensus these days that there are actually objective answers to positive questions.

Sociologists should probably approach observation the way the natural sciences do.
